title: Supply-Demand Marginal Changes Limited, Aluminum Prices ...
summary: LME aluminum closed at $3,195.5/mt, up 0.69%, while SHFE aluminum 2603 closed at 24,380 yuan/mt, up 0.68%. Spot primary aluminum prices edged down, with mainstream transactions at a discount, and aluminum scrap prices showed divergence amid weak downstream demand. The market is expected to hover at highs this week but faces downside pressures ahead of Chinese New Year.

title: Aluminum - Price - Chart - Historical Data - News
summary: Aluminum rose to 3,199.35 USD/T on January 26, up 0.76% from the previous day, with a monthly rise of 8.41% and yearly increase of 22.49%. It further rose to 3,187.55 USD/T, up 0.38%, tracking benchmark market trends. Historical high was 4103 USD/T in March 2022.

title: Press Metal to gain from higher aluminium prices
summary: Press Metal is expected to benefit from higher aluminum prices and favorable alumina costs, with revised LME assumptions at US$2,950 per tonne for 2026. Alumina prices fell 54% year-on-year to US$310 per tonne, improving cost ratios. Forecasts for the company lifted by 5-18% for 2025-2027.

title: US aluminium prices break away as tariffs collide with global supply strain
summary: US aluminum prices surged past USD 5,000 per tonne due to tariffs up to 50%, falling imports, and shrinking stocks, creating a 68% premium over LME prices. Factors include EU sanctions on Russian aluminum, Europe's CBAM, and China's production cap near 45 million tonnes. US smelters like Century Aluminum are ramping up capacity.

title: Andy Home: US aluminium consumers are paying the rising cost of tariffs
summary: US aluminum 'all-in price' exceeds $5,000 per metric tonne due to a $560 physical delivery premium on top of tariffs. Prices rose over 17% in the past year amid supply strains. Consumers face shortages impacting automotive, aerospace, and other industries.

title: EGA signs deal to build first US aluminium plant in almost five decades
summary: Emirates Global Aluminium (EGA) and Century Aluminum announced a joint venture to build a new primary aluminum smelter in Inola, Oklahoma, with a $4 billion investment. The facility will produce 750,000 tonnes of aluminum annually, more than doubling current U.S. production, and create 1,000 permanent jobs plus 4,000 construction positions. Construction is expected to begin by the end of 2026, with production starting before the end of the decade.

title: Century Aluminum joins EGA project to build first U.S. smelter in almost 50 years
summary: Century Aluminum (NASDAQ: CENX) and Emirates Global Aluminium announced a joint development agreement for a 750,000-tonne-per-year primary aluminum smelter in Inola, Oklahoma, with EGA holding 60% and Century 40% ownership. This marks the first new U.S. primary smelter since 1980 and will address the current situation where 85% of domestic aluminum needs are met by imports. Construction is targeted for the end of 2026 with production expected by the end of the decade.

title: Century Aluminum Joins EGA Project to Build First U.S. Smelter in Almost 50 Years
summary: Emirates Global Aluminium and Century Aluminum entered into a joint development agreement to construct the first new primary aluminum production plant in the United States since 1980 in Inola, Oklahoma. The facility will produce 750,000 tonnes annually using EGA's advanced technology, creating 1,000 permanent jobs and 4,000 construction jobs while more than doubling current U.S. production capacity. Detailed engineering is underway with construction expected to start by the end of 2026 and production by the end of the decade.

title: Major Aluminum Project in Oklahoma Promises Thousands of Jobs
summary: Emirates Global Aluminium and Century Aluminum announced a partnership to develop the first new primary aluminum smelter in the U.S. in nearly five decades in Inola, Oklahoma, with planned annual production of 750,000 metric tons. The project will use EGA's most advanced smelting technology and is expected to create approximately 1,000 permanent jobs and 4,000 construction jobs while significantly strengthening domestic aluminum supply. The facility will be located at the Tulsa Port of Inola, providing access to national shipping routes through the Mississippi River system.

title: Sortera Raises $45 Million to Scale AI Driven Aluminum Upcycling
summary: Sortera has secured $45 million to expand its AI-enabled aluminum sorting platform and construct a second U.S. facility in Tennessee. The technology transforms mixed aluminum scrap into targeted alloys, reducing energy demand by up to 95% compared to primary aluminum production and supporting decarbonization efforts. This aligns with U.S. priorities for reshoring manufacturing and reducing foreign supply chain dependency.

title: Century Aluminum Joins EGA Project to Build First U.S. Smelter in Almost 50 Years
summary: Emirates Global Aluminium (EGA) and Century Aluminum have agreed to build a new primary aluminum smelter in Oklahoma, the first in the U.S. since 1980, using advanced EGA technology to double domestic production. The facility will address import dependency for this critical mineral, benefiting industries like automotive, aerospace, and defense while creating manufacturing jobs. Construction is slated to start by late 2026, with production by the end of the decade.

title: Century Aluminum Oklahoma Smelter: $4B Investment Plan
summary: Century Aluminum announces a $4 billion joint venture for an Oklahoma smelter project, reinforcing efforts to bolster America's aluminum supply chain. This initiative highlights vulnerabilities in domestic production and aims to enhance sustainability and security through expanded capacity.

title: NALCO plans to build 200–300 MW renewable power capacity for greener aluminium production
summary: India's NALCO is planning 200-300 MW of renewable power capacity with battery storage to reduce carbon emissions from its aluminum operations, shifting from coal-based power that accounts for 80% of emissions. Despite higher costs, this supports global demand for greener materials and includes ongoing wind and solar installations. The move accompanies refinery expansions to maintain competitiveness in a carbon-conscious market.

title: Steel Falls as China Output Declines
summary: Steel rebar futures fell toward CNY 3,100 per ton, hitting a two-week low after official data showed China’s steel production sank to a seven-year low in 2025 despite strong exports. Annual output dropped 4.4% to 961 million tons, falling below the 1 billion threshold and highlighting weak domestic demand.

title: Nucor increases HRC spot price by $5/ton
summary: Nucor's consumer spot price for hot-rolled coil increased to $965 per short ton, up $5 per short ton from the prior week. The West Coast joint venture price also rose $5 to $1,015 per short ton, with lead times of 3 to 5 weeks continuing.

title: US raw steel production is up 1.3 percent - week 3, 2026
summary: US domestic raw steel production for the week ending January 24, 2026, was 1.778 million net tons at a 76.9% capacity utilization rate, up 1.3% from the prior week. Year-to-date production through January 24 is up 3.4% from the same period in 2025.

title: HRC Steel Hits 5-week Low
summary: HRC Steel decreased to 874.00 USD/T, marking the lowest since November 2025. Over the past 4 weeks, prices gained 0.33%, with a 24.96% increase over the last 12 months.

title: US raw steel production is up 1.3 percent - week 3, 2026
summary: US domestic raw steel production for the week ending January 24, 2026, reached 1.778 million net tons, up 1.3% from the previous week at 1.756 million net tons, with capacity utilization at 76.9%. This represents a 4.6% increase from the same week in 2025. Adjusted year-to-date production through January 24 was 6.016 million net tons at 75.9% capacity utilization, up 3.4% year-over-year.

title: Steel Falls as China Output Declines
summary: China’s steel production fell to a seven-year low of 961 million tons in 2025, down 4.4% year-over-year, due to weak domestic demand despite strong exports. December output hit a two-year low of 68.2 million tons amid property sector strains and government curbs on new capacity. Member mills slightly increased early January output but remained 3.3% below last year's pace.

title: Global Steel Production Drops 2% in 2025 Amid Market Pressures – Worldsteel
summary: Global crude steel production by World Steel Association members fell 3.7% year-over-year to 139.6 million tonnes in December 2025, with full-year 2025 output at 1,803.8 million tonnes, down 2.0% from 2024. Asia and Oceania saw the steepest decline at 6.3%, while the Middle East surged 13.9%. EU-27, Other Europe, and South America showed positive growth.

title: Signs Point to a Bright Future for U.S. Green Steel in 2026
summary: U.S. steel manufacturers are advancing green steel production through innovations like electric arc mini-mills that recycle steel scrap and coal-free processes. Companies like Hertha Metals and Electra are developing technologies that reduce carbon emissions by replacing traditional coal-based methods with electricity and renewable energy, making production more cost-competitive while lowering environmental impact.

title: Digitalization: The Key to Steel Decarbonization
summary: Digital tools are essential for verifying emission reduction claims and improving manufacturing efficiency in steel production. Digitalization enables supply chain transparency and traceability, helping build trust in low-emissions steel by monitoring sustainability credentials throughout production.

title: Future of Steel: Trends, Technology & Sustainability 2026
summary: This article examines upcoming steel industry trends, focusing on sustainability initiatives, scrap recycling practices, and emerging low-carbon technologies that are reshaping steel production in 2026.

title: Innovation and Sustainability Define Top Stainless Steel Manufacturer
summary: This article highlights a leading stainless steel manufacturer's commitment to innovation and sustainability practices in their operations.

title: British Columbia Increases Budget to Assist Mining Rights Approval
summary: LME copper futures opened at $13,139/mt overnight, dipped to $13,033/mt, rose to a high of $13,311/mt, and closed at $13,183/mt, up 0.42%. Shanghai SHFE copper 2602 contract on January 26 showed volatility, opening around 102,830 yuan/mt, peaking at 103,870 yuan/mt, and closing at 102,510 yuan/mt. Guangdong spot #1 copper cathode traded at a discount of 300-120 yuan/mt against the front-month contract, averaging 210 yuan/mt, down from the previous day.

title: Daily Topic of China Commodity Data (January 27, 2026)
summary: On January 26, 2026, SunSirs monitored 96 commodities with year-on-year price increases, including 15 in the non-ferrous sector. Recent updates highlight LME copper rises alongside oil price falls and gold breaking $5,000. The commodity price index BPI reached 952 points, up 9 points from the previous day.

title: Copper prices soar, tin comes under pressure
summary: Copper prices rose to their highest in more than a week on Monday amid expectations of strong demand and supply concerns. The market focused on robust fundamentals supporting the price surge. Tin prices faced downward pressure in contrast.

title: Immediate transition to copper is technically and economically feasible
summary: Rising silver prices are prompting large solar manufacturers to switch to copper for cell metallization, with Chinese firms like Longi adopting copper-based technology. Experts from ISC Konstanz and UNSW indicate that copper-metallized solar modules perform comparably to silver ones with acceptable efficiency trade-offs. This shift could mark 2026 as a milestone in reducing PV industry reliance on costly silver.

title: DRC plans to export 100,000 metric tons of copper to the US
summary: The Democratic Republic of Congo plans to ship 100,000 metric tons of copper from the Tenke Fungurume Mine to the U.S. by end of January, amid U.S. investment in critical minerals. The mine, operated by CMOC Group and Gécamines, supports growing demand from renewables and AI applications. Gécamines aims for long-term sales of up to 500,000 tons of copper from its stakes.

title: Freeport-McMoRan Boosts 2026, 2027 Capex, Advancing Copper Projects
summary: Freeport-McMoRan plans $4.3-$4.5 billion in capex for 2026-2027 to expand U.S. copper production by over 50% in the next 4-5 years, focusing on innovation and facilities. The company supplies 70% of U.S. refined copper and anticipates strong global demand from power grids, renewables, and tech. Q4 2025 results were solid despite Grasberg disruptions, with operations resuming in Q2 2026.

title: Record Copper Prices Highlight the Urgency of New U.S. Supply
summary: Copper prices hit records above $6/lb on COMEX and $13,387/ton on LME due to supply disruptions at mines like Grasberg and Mantoverde, plus trade concerns. Forecasts predict deficits and 24% demand growth by 2035 from electrification. Gunnison Copper restarted production at Johnson Camp Mine in Arizona, advancing sulfide-leaching tech and planning a PEA update.

title: AWS to Source Low Carbon Nuton Copper from Rio Tinto for U.S. Data Center Infrastructure
summary: Amazon Web Services (AWS) will source low-carbon copper produced via Rio Tinto's Nuton technology for its U.S. data centers. Nuton uses microorganisms to extract copper from sulphide ores, reducing water use, emissions, and the need for traditional smelters while producing high-purity copper cathode. This collaboration leverages AWS's cloud analytics to optimize the process, supporting sustainable supply chains amid rising copper demand from AI and cloud computing.

title: CMOC Joins the International Copper Association to Advance Sustainable Industry Development
summary: CMOC Group Limited has joined the International Copper Association (ICA) as its first Chinese member, aiming to advance sustainable copper industry development. The ICA promotes copper's role in clean energy, sustainable communities, and UN Sustainable Development Goals. Membership underscores commitments to responsible production, emissions reduction, and environmental progress in the copper sector.

title: Can Recycling Alone Meet Copper Demand? Let’s Talk Facts
summary: Resolution Copper discusses whether recycling can satisfy growing copper demand for technologies like EVs, renewables, power grids, and electronics. The article highlights copper's essential role in modern infrastructure and sustainable energy systems. It emphasizes the need for new mining to complement recycling amid surging demand.

title: [SMM Nickel Midday Review] Nickel prices experienced a significant correction on January 27 as Trump announced an increase
summary: On January 27, SMM #1 refined nickel prices dropped significantly to an average of 148,100 yuan/mt, down 5,700 yuan/mt from the previous day, amid Trump's announcement of higher tariffs on South Korean goods. SHFE nickel futures also declined 2.48% to 145,200 yuan/mt in the morning session. Despite the correction, nickel prices are likely to rise due to Indonesia's nickel ore quota cuts and supply disruptions.

title: Nickel Prices Jump After Top Producer Indonesia Signals 2026 Output Cut
summary: Indonesia plans to cut nickel production quotas in 2026 to balance supply and demand, causing spot nickel prices to rise to $16,500/tonne from $15,800/tonne and LME three-month contract up 6.4%. The move aims to curb surplus and support prices, similar to DRC's cobalt strategy. Indonesia's market share has grown to 60.2% by 2024.

title: Can nickel prices hit $25,000 in 2026?
summary: Nickel prices surged to $16,500–$18,500/tonne in early January 2026, the highest in over two years, driven by Indonesia delaying permits and slashing output quotas. Markets view this as a shift to supply management, with only 55% of 2025 capacity utilized, potentially pushing prices to $20,000–$22,000/tonne or even $25,000 under tightening conditions.

title: Indonesia cuts 2026 nickel quota, global prices jump immediately
summary: Indonesia's cut to 2026 nickel quotas led to immediate strengthening of LME and Asian nickel prices amid tighter supply concerns. The decision addresses oversupply from Indonesia's dominant production.

title: Nickel Daily Report on 26 January 2026
summary: Daily report on nickel market trends and prices for January 26, 2026, providing updates relevant to recent developments in the nickel sector.

title: Can nickel prices hit $25,000 in 2026?
summary: Nickel prices rallied to $16,500–$18,500 per ton in early January 2026 due to Indonesia delaying mining permits and slashing nickel output quotas, despite producing two-thirds of global supply. Only 55% of Indonesia’s approved nickel ore production capacity was utilized in 2025, revealing a 'paper surplus' illusion. This shift emphasizes high-grade sulphide projects like Canada Nickel’s Crawford project outside Indonesia.

title: Nickel Daily: Indonesia's January (Period II) benchmark prices see a significant increase
summary: Indonesia's January Period II benchmark nickel prices saw a significant increase amid ongoing market dynamics. The article highlights demand trends and references a webinar on 2026 nickel supply-demand balance and new MHP capacity impacts. Related updates include recent nickel ore portside prices in China.

title: Talon Metals Completes Previously Announced Acquisition of Lundin Mining's Eagle Mine and Humboldt Mill Operations Creating a Multi-Asset U.S. Nickel-Copper Company
summary: Talon Metals completed its acquisition of Lundin Mining's Eagle Mine and Humboldt Mill, the only primary nickel mine operating in the U.S., creating a multi-asset nickel-copper company. The deal positions Talon to extend Eagle Mine's life, accelerate exploration, and advance the Tamarack Nickel-Copper-Cobalt Project. This supports U.S. critical minerals self-sufficiency with high-grade assets in Michigan and Minnesota.

title: SPC Nickel sharpens Muskox drill targeting
summary: SPC Nickel’s mobile magnetotelluric survey at the Muskox Project in Nunavut identified a 27km conductive horizon and multiple high-conductivity anomalies prospective for copper-nickel-PGM sulphide mineralization. These targets, open at depth, enhance subsurface understanding and prioritize drill testing for 2026. The project covers 496km² of greenfield polymetallic assets.

title: Indonesia cuts 2026 nickel quota, global prices jump immediately
summary: Indonesia reduced its 2026 nickel production quota, immediately fueling global supply concerns and driving up nickel prices. This policy shift aims to support higher prices amid Indonesia's dominant production role.

title: Indonesia Nickel Production Limits Drive Market Rally
summary: Indonesia's nickel production limits propelled prices to $18,905 per ton by January 2026, a 32.7% increase over six weeks. The restrictions address oversupply perceptions and tighten physical balances.

title: INTERVIEW: Nickel Industries to add battery products, grow ore throughput fivefold by 2026-27
summary: Nickel Industries plans to expand its product mix to include nickel cathode and sulfate for EV batteries, alongside growing ore output to 25 million mt in 2026 from 19 million mt in 2024. The company is commissioning a new HPAL plant and second mine to boost mixed hydroxide precipitate and cobalt production. This positions them to capitalize on growing demand for battery-grade nickel from major manufacturers like CATL.

title: Greener method recovers critical metals from spent batteries
summary: Researchers at Monash University developed a sustainable method using deep eutectic solvents to recover over 95% of high-purity nickel, cobalt, manganese, and lithium from spent lithium-ion batteries, including complex black mass. This greener alternative avoids high temperatures and hazardous chemicals, promoting a circular economy for critical metals. The process shows promise for industrial-scale recycling and reducing environmental impact from battery waste.

title: Can nickel prices hit $25,000 in 2026?
summary: Nickel prices surged to $16,500–$18,500 per ton in early January 2026 amid discussions of potential rallies to $25,000, driven by EV demand despite supply from Indonesia. The article highlights the strategic importance of high-grade, low-carbon nickel sulphide projects like Canada Nickel's Crawford in Ontario for secure supply chains. Indonesia's focus on onshore processing and rising costs may support higher prices for non-Indonesian sources.

title: Indonesia's massive captive coal plans are putting climate targets and economy at risk: study
summary: Indonesia's captive coal capacity for nickel processing has tripled to 31 GW since 2023, risking climate goals, public health, and economic stability. This growth powers nickel smelters critical for EV batteries but emits toxic pollution, potentially causing 27,000 air pollution deaths and $20 billion in costs. Studies warn of environmental degradation eroding economic gains in nickel hubs by 2030.

title: Challenges and opportunities of the EU battery and raw materials industries
summary: An event on January 27 discusses EU strategies for a domestic EV battery value chain, emphasizing nickel and other raw materials for sustainability and reducing China dependency. Speakers from the Nickel Institute highlight opportunities in battery recycling and secure supply chains via initiatives like RESourceEU. The focus is on metals' role in green mobility and the twin transition.

title: PRYSMIAN TO ACQUIRE SUBMARINE CABLE SURVEY & INSTALLATION SOLUTIONS LEADER ACSM
summary: Prysmian plans to acquire Spain-based ACSM, a submarine cable installation company, for €169 million ($198 million). The acquisition will bring subsea surveying, seabed preparation, and installation capabilities in-house, with the transaction expected to close by February.

title: Prysmian, Versalis Launch Chemical Recycling Chain for Plastic Cable Waste in Italy
summary: Prysmian and Versalis have established a strategic partnership for chemical recycling of plastic cable insulation. The pilot project will begin in Italy in the second half of 2026, using Versalis's Hoop® technology to recover up to 60% of difficult-to-recycle XLPE insulation.

title: AGCM Inspection
summary: The Italian Competition Authority (AGCM) conducted an inspection at Prysmian's Italian subsidiary regarding a possible anti-competitive arrangement involving price coordination and commercial sales conditions in the Italian low-voltage copper cable market.
